thread.title: Kim Jong-nam, half-brother of North Korea's Kim Jong-un, killed in Malaysia: reports
thread.title_full: Kim Jong-nam, half-brother of North Korea's Kim Jong-un, killed in Malaysia: reports

title: Kim Jong-nam, half-brother of North Korea's Kim Jong-un, killed in Malaysia: reports
text:
Kim Jong-nam, half-brother of North Korea's Kim Jong-un, killed in Malaysia: reports 128 reading now twitter TWEET More 
The estranged half-brother of North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has been killed in Malaysia, a South Korean government source told Reuters , while other media reported he had been assassinated. 
Kim Jong Nam, the older half brother of the North Korean leader, was known to spend a significant amount of his time outside the country and had spoken out publicly against his family's dynastic control of the isolated state. SHARE Sources said Kim Jong-nam, the half-brother of North Korea's leader, has been killed. Photo: Getty 
He was believed to be in his mid-40s. 
Police in Malaysia told Reuters on Tuesday an unidentified North Korean man had died en route to hospital from Kuala Lumpur airport on Monday. Abdul Aziz Ali, police chief for the Sepang district, said the man's identity had not been verified. SHARE North Korean leader Kim Jong-un pictured in Pyongyang in 2016. Photo: AP 
An employee in the emergency ward of Putrajaya hospital said a deceased Korean there was born in 1970 and had the surname Kim. 
South Korea's TV Chosun, a cable television network, said that Kim was poisoned at Kuala Lumpur airport by two women believed to be North Korean operatives, who remained at large, citing multiple South Korean government sources. Advertisement 
South Korea's foreign ministry said it could not confirm the reports, and the country's intelligence agency could not immediately be reached for comment. 
Kim Jong Nam and Kim Jong Un are both sons of former leader Kim Jong Il, who died in late 2011, but they had different mothers. SHARE Kim Jong Nam's father was former North Korean leader Kim Jong Il. Photo: AP 
Kim Jong Nam was believed to be close to his uncle, Jang Song Thaek, who was North Korea's second most powerful man before being executed on Kim Jong Un's orders in 2013. 
In 2001, Kim Jong Nam was caught at an airport in Japan travelling on a fake passport, saying he had wanted to visit Tokyo Disneyland. 
He said several times over the years that he had no interest in leading his country. 
"Personally I am against third-generation succession," he told Japan's Asahi TV in 2010, before his younger had succeeded their father. 
"I hope my younger brother will do his best for the sake of North Koreans' prosperous lives." 
Reuters
